moves.4... Kxd8: ...forcing his king out of his starting position, so he cannot castle.
moves.6. Be3: Now I bring up my bishop...
moves.6... h6 7. Nh4: ...and eye up his rook and bishop...
moves.8. Nc3: ...so I bring up my other knight...
moves.8... Bb4 9. O-O-O+: ...enabling me to castle, bringing my rook into play, checking my opponent.
moves.9... Nd7 10. Bc4: I eye up his other knight...
moves.10... Ne7: ...but he is again wise to this...
moves.12. Nxf6: ...but I bring its twin on the attack, eyeing up an even better piece (a rook), noticing that the d7 knight is keeping the king out of check.
moves.12... Rf7: That was a real blooper there...
moves.13. Bxf7: ...as the bishop accepts the gift of a more superior rook...
moves.13... gxh4: ...in exchange for a less superior knight...
moves.14. Nxd7: ...and I deem it worth removing one myself, with a slight advantage, especially with more horizontal/vertical power...
moves.15. Be6: ...allowing me to line up the bishop as that is now the piece that is keeping the king out of check...
moves.17. Bc5: ...so I line up the other bishop...
moves.18... cxd6: ...but lose mine, creating yet more space on the board. A 15 point steal in seven moves against 12.
moves.19. Rd3 Rg8 20. g3: This was to stop the remaining rook from getting too deep...
moves.20... hxg3 21. hxg3: ...so I open up the far right-hand side.
moves.21... Rg6 22. f4 exf4 23. gxf4: I decided to swap a pawn apiece, as I am ahead, even if my advantage is slight.
moves.23... Nc6 24. Rdh3: I double up on the far side to line up the pawn...
moves.24... Rg4 25. Rh3h4: ...but line up the rook to save mine...
moves.26... Nd4 27. Rh6h7+ Kc6 28. Kd1 Rg2: My opponent moves his rook deep...
moves.32. Rf1: ...allowing me to split the rook and knight, with the latter under attack from both rooks...
moves.33. Rfxf3: ...and I do likewise to his knight, doubling my rooks on the 3rd rank.
moves.33... a5 34. Rdc3+ Kd5: This played into my hands here...
moves.35... Ke6 36. Rde3: ...allowing me to pin his rook down to the e-file...
moves.37... Kxe4: ...at the expense of one of mine.
moves.38. Rb3: The rook can play the role of the "predator"...
moves.39... Kc5 40. Rb3 a4 41. Rc3+: ...but it has to retreat, and I line up the king this time.
moves.43... axb3: ...giving my opponent no option to take my b-pawn...
moves.44. cxb3: ...creating two passed pawns on my left-hand side.
moves.44... d4 45. Rd3: Now I line up his final pawn...
moves.48... Kc5 49. Rxd4: ...and deem it worth removing the pawn, as removing the rook gives my b-pawn a clear run, while removing the pawn would allow my rook to get back or bring my king up to it.
